automations.title: Xcode
automations.description:
The Automations Package is a lightweight, Swift-based utility designed to streamline automation workflows within your macOS or iOS projects. Whether youâ€™re building productivity tools, internal utilities, or custom scripting interfaces, this package makes it easy to define, manage, and execute groups of named scripts directly within your app.

Ideal for:
- macOS utilities
- Developer tools
- Task automation apps
- Personal productivity tools

scripts.script:
tell application "Xcode"
	activate
	delay 0.5
	tell application "System Events"
		tell process "Xcode"
			keystroke "r" using {command down}
		end tell
	end tell
end tell
scripts.name: Run
scripts.description:
Run Project in Xcode

This automation instantly launches Xcode (if itâ€™s not already active) and triggers the Run command, simulating the âŒ˜R keyboard shortcut. Itâ€™s a quick and reliable way to build and run your current project without manually switching to Xcode or touching your keyboard.

What it does:
	â€¢	Activates the Xcode app
	â€¢	Waits briefly to ensure itâ€™s in focus
	â€¢	Simulates âŒ˜R to start building and running the active scheme

Ideal for integrating into larger workflows or triggering from a companion app, voice assistant, or automation hub.

scripts.script:
tell application "Xcode"
	activate
	delay 0.5
end tell

tell application "System Events"
	tell process "Xcode"
	-- âŒ˜. to stop the current build or run
		keystroke "." using {command down}
	end tell
end tell
scripts.name: Stop
scripts.description:
Stop Build or Run in Xcode

This automation brings Xcode to the foreground and sends the Stop command, equivalent to pressing âŒ˜. (Command + Period). Itâ€™s perfect for quickly halting a running build, simulator session, or active debug process without switching contexts manually.

What it does:
	â€¢	Activates the Xcode app
	â€¢	Waits briefly to ensure itâ€™s ready
	â€¢	Simulates âŒ˜. to stop the current build or run session

Useful for canceling long builds or regaining control during testing workflows with ease.

automations.title: iMovie
automations.description:
Supercharge your iMovie workflows with the Automations Package â€” a Swift-powered utility designed to streamline repetitive editing tasks, enhance project organization, and boost productivity. Perfect for content creators, educators, and teams, this package allows you to define custom script-based actions and apply them directly to your iMovie projects or supporting file structures.


Perfect For:
- YouTubers & Video Editors
- Educators creating tutorials
- Team workflows in shared editing environments
- Anyone looking to save time in repetitive iMovie project tasks

scripts.description:
Split Clip in iMovie

This automation opens iMovie and triggers the Split Clip command, simulating the âŒ˜B keyboard shortcut. Itâ€™s a fast way to cut clips at the playhead position without needing to manually interact with the UI.

What it does:
	â€¢	Brings iMovie to the foreground
	â€¢	Sends âŒ˜B to split the currently selected clip at the playhead

Great for editors who want to streamline their timeline editing or trigger precise cuts as part of a larger automated workflow.
scripts.name: Split At Head
scripts.script:
tell application "iMovie"
	activate
end tell

tell application "System Events"
	tell process "iMovie"
		keystroke "b" using {command down}
	end tell
end tell

automations.title: MacOS
automations.description:
The Automations Package is a powerful Swift-based toolkit designed to simplify and enhance macOS system-level tasks. Perfect for developers, power users, and productivity enthusiasts, this package enables you to define, organize, and trigger customizable system automations with ease.


Perfect For:
- Customizing macOS behavior
- Building internal tools or utilities
- Streamlining repetitive system tasks
- Creating companion iOS/macOS control apps

scripts.name: Theme Switcher
scripts.description:
Toggle macOS Appearance (Light/Dark Mode)

This automation script checks your current macOS system appearance (Light or Dark Mode) and toggles it to the opposite. Itâ€™s ideal for users who want quick control over system appearance â€” useful for scripting, productivity setups, or custom keyboard shortcuts.

What it does:
- Detects whether the system is currently in Light or Dark Mode
- Switches to the opposite mode
- Outputs a confirmation message to the terminal

Perfect for integrating into a larger automation tool or binding to a hotkey for instant theme switching.
scripts.script:
#!/bin/bash

# Check current appearance mode
current_mode=$(osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to tell appearance preferences to get dark mode')

if [ "$current_mode" = "true" ]; then
  # Switch to Light mode
  osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to tell appearance preferences to set dark mode to false'
  echo "Switched to Light Mode"
else
  # Switch to Dark mode
  osascript -e 'tell application "System Events" to tell appearance preferences to set dark mode to true'
  echo "Switched to Dark Mode"
fi

scripts.name: Brightness Up
scripts.description:
This automation raises your Macâ€™s brightness by simulating a press of the Brightness Up key using System Events. Itâ€™s useful for quick brightness adjustments as part of a broader automation workflow, especially when triggered remotely or through scripting tools.

What it does:
	â€¢	Simulates the macOS Brightness Up key
	â€¢	Increases system brightness by one step

Great for integrating into custom control panels, automation hubs, or iOS companion apps.
scripts.script:
tell application "System Events"
    key code 144
end tell

scripts.name: Brightness DOWN
scripts.description:
This automation lowers your Macâ€™s brightness by simulating a press of the Brightness Down key using System Events. Itâ€™s useful for quick brightness adjustments as part of a broader automation workflow, especially when triggered remotely or through scripting tools.

What it does:
	â€¢	Simulates the macOS Brightness Down key
	â€¢	Decreases system brightness by one step

Great for integrating into custom control panels, automation hubs, or iOS companion apps.
scripts.script:
tell application "System Events"
    key code 145
end tell

scripts.name: Volume UP
scripts.description:
This automation raises your Macâ€™s system volume by simulating a press of the Volume Up key using System Events. Itâ€™s useful for quick sound adjustments as part of a broader automation workflow, especially when triggered remotely or through scripting tools.

What it does:
	â€¢	Simulates the macOS Volume Up key
	â€¢	Increases system volume output by 10%

Great for integrating into custom control panels, automation hubs, or iOS companion apps.
scripts.script:
set currentVolume to output volume of (get volume settings)
if currentVolume â‰¤ 90 then
	set volume output volume (currentVolume + 10)
end if

scripts.name: Volume DOWN
scripts.description:
This automation lowers your Macâ€™s system volume by simulating a press of the Volume Down key using System Events. Itâ€™s useful for quick sound adjustments as part of a broader automation workflow, especially when triggered remotely or through scripting tools.

What it does:
	â€¢	Simulates the macOS Volume Down key
	â€¢	Lowers system volume output by 10%

Great for integrating into custom control panels, automation hubs, or iOS companion apps.
scripts.script:
set currentVolume to output volume of (get volume settings)
if currentVolume â‰¥ 10 then
	set volume output volume (currentVolume - 10)
end if
